''With delight,'' Justin replied, ''I would be proud with you for my wife.'' He promised her he would wed her, then left. He spoke to his mother, telling her how things were.

But his mother bickered with him. ''Fine son,'' she told him, ''Tell me no more of this. She is nothing to do with you. She isn't worthy to remove your shoes. I'll see you succeed in life, if it costs me my own. I wish you to seek the friendship of the finest people in the country. I'm shocked you would do this, wishing to wed to this common girl. You'll deserve to be killed if you do not forget this!''
Justin knew by these words, his mother would not concede to his chosen bride. But Love, who rules her subjects, refused to let Justin go. He thought of nothing but Jennifer.

He thought to himself, ''I must figure out, without worry for cost, some plot to see my love.'' Then he spotted the house of the old clothier, Thyre. ''Clothier Tyre, welcome,'' he spoke, hoping to soothe her.
